A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires

( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ........................................ Charles Mycroft

2. Your address ........................................... Russell, W. - 8-100a

3. Date ......................................................... April 35

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Higham, Derbyshire, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year) April 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 20 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   A strong disposition, adventure.
   Interested in farming.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).

    Through a friend who had spent a short time in Canada.

11. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? (If you have answered this question elsewhere, you need not answer it again)

    Farming
1. Your full name: Charles Mycroft

2. Your address: 411 South Street

3. Date: April 25, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Afghanistan

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April 1908

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use I was a small child, etc.) If yes in my teens, etc., 20 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West? A strong desire for adventure, interested in farming.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people, reading about it?) Through a friend who had spent a short time in Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Generally accepted as a sporting proposition.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Alone.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Traveled by boat from Liverpool to New York, left the day after the Base Hospital,
   arrived Saskatoon 6 days ahead of them.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
   meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   My journey from New York to Ottawa was marked by the extreme friendliness of the other passengers.
   Stop over at Kingston, in the station waiting room was a superior or hutton situated almost center.
   There laymen seats around waiting room occupied chiefly by men, an oil lamp on wall.
   It was an amazing exhibition which I had never before witnessed.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   In a tent.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   S.W. ¼ 24-31 W. 3rd meridian.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   None. Resided 4½ years on the homestead.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Generally accepted as a good decision.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Alone

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Travelled by train from Liverpool to New York. Took the day after the train arrived in Western Canada.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

My family came from New York to Western Canada via the Canadian Pacific Railway. We stayed at a hotel in Edmonton, Alberta, before settling in our new home near Calgary. We encountered many challenges along the way, including harsh weather conditions and difficult terrain.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

For a short time

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Saskatoon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Phone: Resided in Saskatoon for two years

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Frequently

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Kate Brad, Delaware, England
Married St. James Church, Montana, June, 1910.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Yes.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

One sister in 1910, married & settled on farm in the Glebow District.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

For many, but of no particular importance.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Have traveled beyond Saskatoon.
Regular church attendance.

26. Popular places all winter.
25. When was the first car used in the community?  
   Around 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?  
   Clinton 2½ miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).  
   Yes, Railway & P.R. built 1908. Frequent visits to Saskatoon.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?  
   We traveled by horse & wagon, consequently trips infrequent.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?  
   As soon as the Town was built.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.  
   Mail order catalogues arrived after railroads built. Household necessities, dry goods etc.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?  
   1911

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?  
   When I first came I didn't know what to expect. The life here made a strong appeal to me & have never left Saskatchewan except for a visit to my birthplace. I am very proud of our province & its many accomplishments & contributions & development during the last 50 years.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, whom did you buy it from? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? 12½ miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? We knew what we wanted.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in bills and installments? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any change in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time, was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

When you came, I didn't want to accept a farm house half barbed wire fence, a small lot, no many advantages. Only way around our farm was to many advantages.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, three families, all English, left for B.C., still residing there.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Some of our earlier settlers, chiefly American, left during the depression & failed to return.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Wheat Pool delegate, Taylor (Chairman of Board), President of Union Bank, 1930.

Candidate in 1934 for Farmer Labor Group, Western Labor Candidate 1944 for B.C. Federal Position.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
1. The influence created by the development of farm organization handling grain by large elevators, etc., later with pools, etc.
2. Development of growth in consumer goods.
3. There in turn gave birth to a new political party.
4. The importance of these developments have a great stabilizing effect on our agricultural economy.
5. The introduction of modern farm machinery.
